results.title: Hollywood Costume: What is Costume Design? with Prof. D. Nadoolman Landis
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In a special event held at ACMI as part of the ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition, curator Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis introduced the art of costume design and discussed its role in cinematic storytelling.
Landis, an Oscar®-nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘The Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is also the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning exhibition catalogue, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes.
Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.

results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Christophe Lautrette
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Christophe Lautrette served the role of a Production Designer for DreamWorks Animation’s pre-historic family comedy, ‘The Croods’. During his tenure at DreamWorks Animation, Lautrette has worked as Art Director on various feature films, including ‘Prince of Egypt’, ‘Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron’, ‘Kung Fu Panda’ and ‘Bee Movie’. He is also the main contributor to DreamWorks Animation’s first personal art publication ‘Moonshine’.

Lautrette is originally from France and he currently resides in Los Angeles, CA.

results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.

results.title: Circus nomads
results.creator_credit: David Hughes, Ivan Gaal, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: This film aims to portray the circus as a nomadic way of life, to give viewers a deeper insight into aspects of circus life, and to show the circus as a form of theatre where the clown is king.

results.title: The Secondary Teacher
results.creator_credit: E.J. Perry and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: Describes the life of secondary student teachers in training: accommodation in a boarding house in Armadale, Victoria, for those from the country areas; Melbourne University and the various courses available for students. Also gives details about specialised couses and shows classes in progress. Shows the science, commerce, music and engineering faculties. Narrated by Terry Dear and animation by the Owen Brothers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: E.J. Perry and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

results.title: [Unidentified 16mm Film]
results.brief_description: Film contains silent footage of various vaudeville and circus-style performances including dancing, acrobatics, slapstick comedy and more. The film also includes extensive footage of the British Navy marching in a street parade in Melbourne. One shot appears to be Elizabeth Street, featuring trams and the Flinders Street Station clocktower.

results.title: Report on Eppalock
results.creator_credit: Robert Rothols, Soil Conservation Authority of Victoria and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Lake Eppalock, and its catchment area are the base for a unique water and soil conservation scheme. The area in the past has suffered severe erosion due to gold mining and bad farming. The aims of this long term project are to heal erosion, conserve water, reclaim land and increase farming production with the co-operation of land holders, shire councils and various Government departments.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Rothols, Soil Conservation Authority of Victoria and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: [Maryborough mudbrick dome]
results.brief_description:
Film showing the construction of a mudbrick hut with domed roof in Maryborough, central Victoria. The hut sits alongside the Maryborough Centenary Reserve, just off Stoneham Drive.

The hut was constructed during a week long workshop with Melbourne arhitecture students and local sustainability enthusiasts including Bill Mollison. The project was featured in ‘The Owner Builder” issue 5 and was overseen by Nepalese architect, Ramesh Manandhar, who is interviewed in the film.

The soundtrack is intermittent.
